_link.title: I can identify beta decay on a decay series diagram

toLevel2.stem: How does beta-minus decay appear on a decay series diagram?
options: A diagonal arrow pointing left and down
A vertical arrow pointing straight down
A diagonal arrow pointing left and up

feedback.correct: Correct! Beta-minus decay is shown as a horizontal arrow pointing right because the atomic number increases by 1 while the mass number stays the same.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Beta-minus decay appears as a horizontal arrow pointing right on a decay series diagram.

toLevel2.stem: What happens to the mass number during beta-minus decay?

feedback.correct: Correct! During beta-minus decay, a neutron converts to a proton, so the total number of nucleons (mass number) remains unchanged.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. In beta-minus decay, the mass number stays the same because a neutron becomes a proton—no nucleons are added or removed.

toLevel2.stem: What happens to the atomic number during beta-minus decay?

feedback.correct: Correct! In beta-minus decay, a neutron converts to a proton, increasing the atomic number by 1.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Beta-minus decay increases the atomic number by 1 because a neutron transforms into a proton.

toLevel2.stem: On the uranium-238 decay series diagram, the decay from Th-234 to Pa-234 is shown as what type of arrow?
options: A horizontal arrow pointing right, indicating beta decay
A diagonal arrow pointing left and down, indicating alpha decay
No arrow because no decay occurs
A vertical arrow pointing down, indicating gamma emission

feedback.correct: Correct! The Th-234 to Pa-234 transition is beta-minus decay (Z increases from 90 to 91, A stays at 234), shown as a horizontal right arrow.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Th-234 to Pa-234 is beta decay, represented by a horizontal arrow pointing right.

toLevel2.stem: Which particle is emitted during beta-minus decay?

feedback.correct: Correct! Beta-minus decay emits an electron (and an antineutrino) when a neutron converts to a proton.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Beta-minus decay emits an electron when a neutron in the nucleus transforms into a proton.

toLevel2.stem: Beta-minus decay on a decay series diagram is shown as a diagonal arrow pointing left and down.

feedback.correct: Correct! That description matches alpha decay. Beta-minus decay is shown as a horizontal arrow pointing right.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Diagonal left-down describes alpha decay. Beta-minus decay is horizontal, pointing right.

toLevel2.stem: In beta-minus decay, the mass number remains unchanged while the atomic number increases by 1.

feedback.correct: Correct! Beta-minus decay converts a neutron to a proton, so A stays the same but Z increases by 1.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. This statement is true—beta-minus decay keeps A constant while increasing Z by 1.

toLevel3.stem: Why does beta-minus decay appear as a horizontal arrow on decay diagrams rather than a diagonal arrow?
options: Because only the atomic number changes while the mass number stays the same
Because beta particles travel in horizontal paths
Because beta decay releases no energy
Because the nucleus moves horizontally in space during decay

feedback.correct: Correct! Beta decay changes Z by 1 (horizontal movement on diagram) but doesn't change A (no vertical movement), resulting in a horizontal arrow.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. The horizontal arrow reflects that only Z changes (+1) while A remains constant—no vertical component.

toLevel3.stem: How does beta-minus decay help a nucleus move toward the belt of stability?
options: It converts a neutron to a proton, reducing the neutron-to-proton ratio for neutron-rich nuclei
It removes excess protons from the nucleus
It adds neutrons to balance the proton count
It releases all the nuclear binding energy at once

feedback.correct: Correct! Neutron-rich nuclei undergo beta-minus decay to convert neutrons to protons, decreasing the n/p ratio toward stability.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Beta-minus decay reduces the neutron-to-proton ratio by converting neutrons to protons, helping neutron-rich nuclei reach stability.

toLevel3.stem: Comparing alpha and beta-minus decay on a diagram, why does alpha decay show a larger shift than beta decay?
options: Alpha decay changes both Z and A significantly, while beta decay only changes Z by 1 with no A change
Alpha particles are larger than electrons
Beta decay is slower than alpha decay
Alpha decay occurs at higher temperatures than beta decay

feedback.correct: Correct! Alpha decay shifts the nucleus diagonally (ΔZ=-2, ΔA=-4), while beta decay moves it only horizontally (ΔZ=+1, ΔA=0).
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Alpha decay produces larger shifts because it changes both Z and A, whereas beta decay only changes Z.

toLevel3.stem: On a decay series diagram, an arrow goes from one nucleus to another with no vertical change but moves one unit to the right. What decay does this represent and why?
options: Beta-minus decay, because Z increases by 1 while A stays the same
Alpha decay, because the nucleus loses particles
Gamma decay, because only energy is released
Positron emission, because the arrow points right

feedback.correct: Correct! No vertical change means A is constant. Moving right means Z increases. This combination identifies beta-minus decay.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. A horizontal rightward arrow (no A change, Z+1) specifically identifies beta-minus decay.

toLevel3.stem: Why does beta-minus decay occur in the uranium-238 decay series between some alpha decays?
options: Alpha decay leaves the daughter nucleus neutron-rich, requiring beta decay to adjust the neutron-to-proton ratio
Beta decay is required by law to occur after every alpha decay
The nucleus randomly chooses between alpha and beta decay
Beta decay provides the energy needed for the next alpha decay

feedback.correct: Correct! After alpha decay, the daughter may be neutron-rich and need beta-minus decay to reduce its n/p ratio before another alpha decay can occur.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Beta decay adjusts the neutron-to-proton ratio when alpha decay leaves a neutron-rich daughter nucleus.

toLevel3.stem: If a nucleus at position (Z=90, A=234) undergoes beta-minus decay, where does it appear on the decay diagram?

feedback.correct: Correct! Beta-minus decay increases Z by 1 (90→91) while keeping A the same (234).
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Beta-minus decay: Z+1, A unchanged. From (90, 234) → (91, 234).

feedback.correct: Correct! Beta-minus decay actually decreases the neutron count by converting a neutron to a proton, reducing the neutron-to-proton ratio.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Beta-minus decay decreases neutrons (converts them to protons), reducing the n/p ratio to help reach stability.

toLevel4.stem: A decay diagram shows a nucleus at (Z=91, A=234). After one decay step, it appears at (Z=92, A=234). What decay occurred and what is the decay equation?

feedback.correct: Correct! Z increases by 1 with A unchanged indicates beta-minus decay. Pa-234 emits an electron to become U-234.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. ΔZ=+1 with ΔA=0 indicates beta-minus decay: ²³⁴₉₁Pa → ²³⁴₉₂U + ⁰₋₁e.

toLevel4.stem: You need to plot the beta-minus decay of lead-214 (Z=82, A=214) on a decay diagram. Where should you place the daughter nucleus?

feedback.correct: Correct! Beta-minus decay: Z+1, A unchanged. Lead-214 (82, 214) → Bismuth-214 (83, 214).
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Beta-minus decay increases Z by 1 and keeps A the same: (82, 214) → (83, 214).

toLevel4.stem: A student sees an arrow on a decay diagram going from (Z=83, A=214) to (Z=84, A=214). They identify this as alpha decay. Is this correct?
options: No, this is beta-minus decay because Z increased by 1 while A stayed the same
Yes, this is alpha decay because the element changed
No, this is gamma decay because no particles were emitted
Yes, this is alpha decay because the atomic number changed

feedback.correct: Correct! Alpha decay would show ΔZ=-2 and ΔA=-4. Here, ΔZ=+1 and ΔA=0, which identifies beta-minus decay.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. ΔZ=+1 with ΔA=0 is beta-minus decay, not alpha decay (which would be ΔZ=-2, ΔA=-4).

toLevel4.stem: Starting from Th-234 (Z=90, A=234), two consecutive beta-minus decays occur. What nucleus results?

feedback.correct: Correct! Each beta-minus decay: Z+1, A unchanged. After two: Z = 90+2 = 92, A = 234. This is U-234.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Two beta-minus decays: Z increases by 2 total (90→92), A stays at 234, giving U-234.

toLevel4.stem: On a decay series diagram, you observe the sequence: diagonal left-down arrow, then horizontal right arrow. What decay sequence does this represent?
options: Alpha decay followed by beta-minus decay
Beta-minus decay followed by alpha decay
Gamma emission followed by alpha decay

feedback.correct: Correct! Diagonal left-down = alpha decay (ΔZ=-2, ΔA=-4). Horizontal right = beta-minus decay (ΔZ=+1, ΔA=0).
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Left-down diagonal is alpha; horizontal right is beta-minus.

toLevel4.stem: A researcher analyzing a decay diagram needs to count all beta-minus decays in a series. What visual pattern should they look for?
options: Horizontal arrows pointing to the right
Diagonal arrows pointing left and down

feedback.correct: Correct! Beta-minus decay appears as horizontal rightward arrows (Z+1, A unchanged) on decay diagrams.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Beta-minus decays are represented by horizontal arrows pointing right.

toLevel4.stem: The uranium-238 series includes 6 beta-minus decays. What is the total change in atomic number due to these beta decays alone?

feedback.correct: Correct! Each beta-minus decay increases Z by 1. Six beta decays: ΔZ = 6 × (+1) = +6.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Each beta-minus decay increases Z by 1, so 6 decays give a total change of +6.

toLevel5.stem: The uranium-238 series has 8 alpha decays (ΔZ = -16) and 6 beta-minus decays (ΔZ = +6). Analyze why this combination results in lead (Z=82) as the final product.
options: The net change is -16 + 6 = -10, which transforms uranium (Z=92) to lead (Z=82)
The alpha and beta decays cancel out, leaving Z unchanged
Only the alpha decays matter; beta decays have no effect on final Z
The combination is coincidental and could result in any element

feedback.correct: Correct! Alpha contributes -16 to Z, beta contributes +6. Net: -10. Starting at Z=92, ending at Z=92-10=82 (lead).
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. The combination of alpha (ΔZ=-16) and beta (ΔZ=+6) gives net ΔZ=-10, transforming U(92) to Pb(82).

toLevel5.stem: In decay series diagrams, beta-minus decays often follow alpha decays. Analyze what this pattern reveals about nuclear stability.
options: Alpha decay produces neutron-rich daughters that need beta-minus decay to reduce their n/p ratio toward stability
Beta decay must legally follow every alpha decay in nuclear physics
Alpha decay depletes all protons, requiring beta decay to restore them
The pattern is random and reveals nothing about nuclear stability

feedback.correct: Correct! Alpha decay removes 2 protons and 2 neutrons equally, but heavy nuclei need more neutrons than protons, so daughters are often neutron-rich and need beta-minus decay.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Alpha decay can leave daughters neutron-rich, requiring beta-minus decay to adjust the n/p ratio toward the belt of stability.

toLevel5.stem: A student claims that "beta decay is less significant than alpha decay in decay series because it doesn't change the mass number." Evaluate this claim.
options: The claim is flawed because beta decay is essential for adjusting the neutron-to-proton ratio to reach stable isotopes
The claim is correct because mass number is the only important nuclear property
The claim is correct because beta decay contributes nothing to the decay series
The claim is flawed because beta decay actually changes the mass number more than alpha decay

feedback.correct: Correct! While beta decay doesn't change A, it's crucial for adjusting the n/p ratio. Without beta decays, the series couldn't reach the stable end product.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Beta decay is essential—it adjusts the neutron-to-proton ratio, which is necessary for reaching stable end products.

toLevel5.stem: Comparing two decay paths: Path A has 4 alpha and 2 beta-minus decays; Path B has 3 alpha and 4 beta-minus decays. Analyze the net atomic number change for each path.
options: Path A: ΔZ = -6; Path B: ΔZ = -2
Path A: ΔZ = -10; Path B: ΔZ = -10
Path A: ΔZ = +2; Path B: ΔZ = +6
Path A: ΔZ = -8; Path B: ΔZ = -7

feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Calculate: Path A = 4×(-2) + 2×(+1) = -6. Path B = 3×(-2) + 4×(+1) = -2.

toLevel5.stem: A textbook shows a decay series where an arrow goes from (Z=84, A=214) horizontally to (Z=83, A=214). Evaluate whether this correctly represents a decay process.
options: This is incorrect for beta-minus decay, which should increase Z; this arrow suggests beta-plus decay or electron capture
This is correct beta-minus decay representation
This is correct alpha decay representation
This cannot represent any known decay process

feedback.correct: Correct! Beta-minus increases Z (moves right). A leftward horizontal arrow (Z decreasing) would represent beta-plus decay or electron capture, not beta-minus.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Horizontal movement to lower Z (left) indicates beta-plus decay or electron capture, not beta-minus (which moves right).

toLevel5.stem: The thorium-232 series has 6 alpha decays and 4 beta-minus decays to reach lead-208. Verify this is consistent by analyzing the change from Th-232 (Z=90) to Pb-208 (Z=82).
options: Inconsistent: the numbers don't add up to the correct final Z
Cannot be verified without knowing the exact decay sequence

feedback.correct: Correct! Alpha: 6×(-2) = -12. Beta-minus: 4×(+1) = +4. Net: -8. From Z=90: 90-8 = 82 (lead). ✓
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. The math works: 6 alphas (-12) + 4 betas (+4) = -8. Starting from Th (90): 90-8 = 82 (Pb).

toLevel5.stem: A researcher proposes that decay series could theoretically reach the same end product using only alpha decays or only beta decays. Evaluate this proposal.
options: This is impossible because alpha-only would give wrong Z, and beta-only cannot reduce mass number to reach lighter stable isotopes
This is possible with any combination of decays
This is only possible for light elements, not heavy ones
This is possible if enough time is allowed for all decays to complete

feedback.correct: Correct! Alpha-only can't adjust the n/p ratio properly. Beta-only can't reduce mass number. Both types are needed to reach stable lead isotopes.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Alpha decay reduces A but doesn't optimize n/p ratio alone. Beta decay can't reduce A at all. Both are necessary.

toLevel5.stem: On the U-238 decay diagram, consecutive horizontal right arrows sometimes appear (e.g., Th-234 → Pa-234 → U-234). Analyze what these consecutive beta decays indicate about the intermediate nuclei.
options: Both intermediate nuclei are significantly neutron-rich and need multiple beta-minus decays to approach the belt of stability
The decay series has an error because consecutive beta decays are impossible
The consecutive decays indicate the nuclei have too many protons
Consecutive beta decays mean the mass number is decreasing rapidly

feedback.correct: Correct! Consecutive beta-minus decays indicate severely neutron-rich nuclei that need multiple n→p conversions to reach favorable neutron-to-proton ratios.
feedback.incorrect: Incorrect. Consecutive beta-minus decays show that the daughter nuclei remain neutron-rich and need continued adjustment of their n/p ratios.

toLevel5.stem: Analyzing decay series, beta-minus decays compensate for the [[1]] in atomic number caused by alpha decays, allowing the series to reach the [[2]] Z value for lead.

feedback.allCorrect: Correct! Alpha decays decrease Z too much; beta-minus decays partially compensate by increasing Z, achieving the correct final value.
feedback.someIncorrect: Not quite. Beta-minus decays offset some of the Z decrease from alpha decays to reach the correct final Z.
